review_title: Racism, Nepotism, Cronyism, Misogynoir, Mismanagement, Internal Mess
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are decent. That's it. Full stop. There are no other pros to this job.
cons: Racism, nepotism, cronyism, misogynoir, mismanagement, internal mess. Infighting, no cooperation, rife with nasty characters and bad actors. One of the most traumatic and horrible work experiences of my life. Do not apply here. Run! I saw a bad review for this place right before accepting the job and assumed it was just a one-off; just one individual with a negative experience. That sort of thing happens all the time. But I should have heeded their warning. AltaMed stole years of my life and I am still paying the price. They ran me into the ground, worked me sick, and just kept taking. Please heed this warning. No amount of desperation is worth working here. Trust me, it's not worth it.

review_title: Vision, mission and values driven community health center advancing health equity
job_title: Chief Operations Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I've worked at universities and private medical groups where the margin is more important than mission, and there is no reinvestment of those dollars back into the community. AltaMed's mission of eliminating health disparities, while not easy, inspires me to continue fighting to improve primary care for underserved communities. As a physician leader, we are driving the strategic direction of this organization to expand the reach of our mission, while improving primary care for the communities we serve. We have great respect for our nurses and non-clinicians who are integral team members to help us live our mission. Our patient's needs and conditions are dire, given their social and clinical complexity, but this is why working here makes this that much more rewarding. As a state/country we cannot afford to keeping leaving impovershed communities behind.
cons: Our mission is not for everyone. Some physicians believe that they can come to underserved communities and practice outdated medicine. We are welcoming and we strongly believe everyone can practice evidence-based high-quality primary care. We monitor employee engagement, patient satisfaction, quality and population health outcomes and value-based care. Establishing and caring for a primary care panel of underserved patients can be difficult and we support our providers with resources, tools and feedback. This pandemic while challenging for everyone in healthcare, has also helped continue investing in our clinical teams and improve our services.

review_title: Join if you want toxic workplace experience
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Commerce, CA
pros: HMO insurance is pretty good.
cons:
Everything else. Pay is below average. The leadership simply doesn't care about bottom line employees.

Nepotism runs rampant at the top. CEO and CAO are married. Bunch of other c level execs are sons, daughters, cousins or nephews. The family tree would shock you. 

If you're not a de la Rocha or Escobar, don't expect great things.

We have top level leaders like the CAO, who demands people to show up to the office or she doesn't trust you... Yet blocks her calendar to study for school remotely. 

The hypocrisy is jaw dropping. There is so much disconnect between what the
company needs to move forward vs the desires and the wishes of Castulo and Zoila.
Their idea for increased retention is to preach the good ol days. That gospel will not make this an "employer of choice." The 5 star reviews on this are fake and done by the comm department. I recognize their writing style. Some are obviously sarcastic. 

My goal is to achieve a good answer to the interview question "so tell me a time you had to overcome a negative working experience." And man, I'll have pages and pages of cited references and stories.

pros: I have worked in the health care and education field for over 25 years. Of all the organizations I have been part of, AltaMed has been THE best at caring for its employees and most importantly its clients- the patients. Every single day, I feel myself and my fellow AltaMed colleagues are devoted to providing the best care possible to our often over looked and underresourced communities. As a new leader to the organization I am provided with resources, training, and support. I could not be happier and plan to retire here.
cons: Nothing and no one is perfect. I can honestly say that our leadership continues to listen to us and values our voices. They are always looking for innovative ideas to support our work and our outside lives.

review_title: They do not value physicians, treat us as disposable
job_title: Physician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great patient demographic, you feel appreciated by the patient. Back and front staff are also very team-oriented.
cons: Administrator heavy, physicians truly lack autonomy—your value is based on short term outcomes, not evidence-based long-term MIPS. It is simply a matter of how many patients can you see in an hour. RVU’s. You get zero time to call patients, check labs, document, coordinate care. You’re scheduled every single minute of the day except your lunch which you’re not paid for but you end up doing all admin work. Admin basically decide what you can and can’t do—how long you need for what type of patient etc. A rubber stamp CMO who is the nephew of the owner (?) just agrees with whatever will continue to generate more profits for his family. Nepotism is alive and well. While I was there, three of us physicians resigned within 4 months and all of us were truly dedicated to our patients. Altamed treated us like we were truly replaceable. They don’t value continuity of care—they see physicians as ‘providers’ which is actually what they call us. They don’t think about whether a patient may actually have built a certain relationship with their physician. They just see us as ‘that’s a provider, we’ll just get another provider’. They also cut physician salary by 10% during the pandemic but not administrators. We were frontline. That tells you two things; 1. Who is making the actual decisions. 2. How valued physicians are. Like most of these systems, they have about 5 X more admins than they need and not enough physicians in leadership. They top has no idea how to connect with let alone impact the frontline in an effective way. They can only drive us away and ultimately, patients follow. so do other physicians bc we are not loyal to institutions, we follow other physicians (not providers by the way).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay is reasonable. SOME employees are extremely helpful. Vacation days- easy.  Great to gain experience, add on resume and RUN!!
cons: Management truly does not appreciate hard work and dedication. You get thrown out with very little training . Especially if you are either a weekend or closing staff. Management does not want to cover any longer than they should even if you are not fully trained. I learned a lot by doing it “the wrong way” first. A lot of my teaching came from the medical assistants,  they are a lot more knowledgeable than the rest of the LVNs and RNs in this clinic. RNs are never on the floor, they only answer phones.  I would have stayed here a lot longer and possibly retired here if it was not for the way employees are treated. Everyone is always in a bad mood and has a bad attitude due to being treated the way they are. Treat employees with respect = they will do the same.  I’ve witnessed management yelling at employees at the nurses station infront of other employees and patients. Extremely unprofessional.

job_title: Management in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The front line staff to middle management are very mission driven and passionate about serving under-served communities. Many opportunities to grow for early professionals since it's a growing and dynamic organization.
cons: Senior Leaders do not have the culture of teamwork, business acumen or leadership skills to commit to goals, thoughtfully plan 1 to 3 year actions and execute the plan. The CEO continues to blatant practice nepotism and does not practice data driven decision-making. Many of them are protecting their legacies by trying to win awards like Baldridge and blindly copying more mature organizations like Kaiser vs. building up the foundation of talent and leaders. As a result the "us vs. corporate" silos have grown, trust no-one politicking continues and the good and kind leaders are marginalized and squeezed out. It's very sad to see.

review_title: Great in Theory - Bad in Practice

pros:

- No framework or infrastructure to support any department.
- I don't honestly know if AltaMed's leadership does not know about all of the horrible problems the company is facing or if they simply just don't care.
- The answer to so many of AltaMed's problems is to just throw money at it until it goes away. AltaMed is one whistleblower lawsuit away from going out of business just like SynerMed.

review_title: Turns the other cheek at shady co-workers, clique management, greedy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: My dept had a very flexible schedule with telecommuting opportunities. The pay was a bit higher than average for my industry.
cons: The President Castulo makes $900,000 a year that is paid for by tax payer dollars. They only care about money, they cram a bunch of patients in at one time leaving the patients to wait upwards of 2 hours after their scheduled appointment times. They have staff that are fraudulent and inappropriate yet they turn the other cheek because they don't want to lose any more staff.  High turn-over rate. Working here you move up based on who you know and how much you kiss up to staff. You can have no degree and supervise people with their master's degrees just because they are in the right clique.

job_title: RN Out Patient Case Manager in Commerce, CA
pros: good benefits, medical insurance starts next month of hire. 6 hours a month of PTO. 8 Paid holidays. Tuition reimbursement. Student loan forgiveness
cons: I stayed many many days after 5; worked during lunch. no quality of life. I promise you will cry some days....

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Commerce, CA
pros:
*You get great benefits
*You work next to the Citadel
cons: *Senior Leaders are very rude and treat their employees really bad. As you can read from other comments, they feel the same way. It is true. If you report to HR that your manager is treating you badly, they will find a way to get back at you and write you up. They have their favorite people they protect. If you are new, get ready for a battle. They are a lot of group (clicks) of people that will not be nice to you only because they see you as a threat. There is a lot of inappropriate behavior from managers to staff and there is a lawsuit waiting to happen, especially because of the "me too" movement and probably a lawsuit for discrimination and harassment waiting to happen.

review_title: Employees are no longer their Greatest Asset.....

pros:

job_title: LVN in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Cheap vending machines. Many Locations
cons: As an LVN it's a scary place to work. Since the company tries to cut corners to save money they make the employees do the work of many. For example, LVN's are considered supervisors. Not only are you expected to perform clinical duties but you are also expected to supervise the Medical Assistants, triage, order supplies, manage the schedule, clean instruments, do your own phlebotomy (only Pico location has Quest on site), complete the billing and pretty much anything else they throw at you. I've never worked in a place like this. They really over demand and over work the LVN. I fear for my license because there is soooo much room for errors. Keep looking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Well-maintained facilities
Some nice co-workers
Occasional morale boosters for the office (eg, cake for birthdays, raffles)
cons:
This company purports itself to be non-profit health CARE entity, but spends way too much money on managerial staff who are not even remotely involved in patient care. Doctors are under-appreciated for the amount of work they do; many seem stressed to the max.
Management can play favorites and be inflexible.
Candidates are selected to positions based on who they know in the company, not their skill set. TONS of nepotism -- it is well-known that there are certain people in charge (despite being sorely under-qualified for their positions) only because of who they know/who they are related to and not based on talents/skills.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Mission. Okay benefits. Match 401k. Great coworkers. Friendly atmosphere (aside from a few supervisors)
cons:
Employees are unappreciated. PTO is a nightmare and impossible to get days off even requesting it months before! You can have your wedding and honeymoon planned and still won’t know if it’s approved until a couple weeks before. We recently got a new system for PTO so hopefully this works out! 

We can’t place patients on hold even though they ask for first call resolution. If you place a patient on hold  you are asked to send a message to the Dr and his team even though there are 3 unanswered message in that same week. (Messages are supposed to be answered within 24-48 hrs) Many messages aren’t followed up or read so patients keep calling back. But if you resolve it on the first call and place them on hold if needed maybe they won’t call back!! 

Not at all flexible with schedules. In the interview you are told they are flexible and will work with your school schedule... well that’s a lie. The Call center is unappreciated not just by management but by many departments throughout the company. We deal closely with the clinic and all day long we are talked down upon and treated rudely. 

At first I thought this was a great company to work for. Now I see it’s really not. Some supervisors at the call center are really cool, treat you with respect and are super friendly. Others not so much. They’ll have their bad days and take it out on you, they’ll give you a hard time and pass your desk OFTEN and micromanage you even though you’ve been working here for years and know what to do. Some supervisors weren’t hired within the company and don’t know anything about the calls we deal with daily. Most, if not ALL, representatives know more than some of these supervisors. How are we going to ask a supervisor to handle an escalated call when they don’t even know the work? 

I’m currently looking for a new place of work. The only thing I’ll miss here are really just my coworkers.

job_title: Social Worker III in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I love my coworkers and the population I work with. 
I think it's an easy job; the caseload is manageable
cons:
As an MSW I do not feel challenged by the work, and there's limited room for growth. Because a lot of supervisors are often not MSWs, they are unable to recognize potential even after it is pointed out. I wish they had LCSWs supervise MSWs.
AltaMed does not provide supervision for MSWs that want to work toward licensing, which is the biggest drawback.

review_title: A mix of crazy that will expose you while stripping you, beware
job_title: Case Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-competitive pay compared to industry 
-they have their own gym for employees at corporate office in LA that is extremely low cost
-great exposure to community health, community based org
-lots of developmental oppurtunities
-org cares about employee engagement and does lots to promote this
-education reimbursement after being with company for 1 year
-lots of really bright people to be around
-CEO is great, humble, down to earth
-great community events (East LA meets Napa, Catrinas Unidas, annual employee meeting, etc)
cons:
-they will work you to the ground
-if you are in an exempt position, good luck- you will be working well over 50 hours/week
-very manager heavy- so many leaders across organization, leads to too many hands in the pot
-needs greater alignment across org-too many departments work in silos
-so many initiatives going on that don't necessarily align to  where the organization is going-becomes difficult to talk about projects ROI- this is a problem for leadership
-org is moving at a faster pace than they can handle
-many people have been there for YEARS that are not necessarily qualified for the place that healthcare is in now-no longer qualified
-many positions are grant funded/ contracted

cons: There is no room for development as a professional other than the fact that you need to wear a tie.

job_title: Former PSA in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Favoritism..u have to be part of the in crowd or u r out.  Manipulation and threat of being written up if u do not do what they want.  A lot of us have left..thanks to a few good people that use to work there that appreciated us and made us realize we r much better than Chla Altamed.

job_title: Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay was the only decent thing...
cons:
Incompetent people get promoted first and foremost.

They give feedback to employees about how everyone does or does not like your work----yes, you read that correct. They do this instead of encouraging adults to have grown up conversations.

- Biggest revolving door I have ever seen at a company of this size. 

- Many people do not like you when they find out you are more competent than they are--makes work difficult.

Last: I was never treated more poorly in my educated professional career--until I came to AltaMed.

...work here at your own risk
